questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation, what is the recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio for a neonate requiring chest compressions?
Which of the following APGAR score interpretations is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: A score of 7-10 is generally considered normal

options.label: B
options.text: A score of 4-6 indicates moderate distress

options.label: C
options.text: A score of 0-3 suggests severe distress and requires immediate intervention

options.label: D
options.text: The APGAR score at 1 minute is used to predict long-term neurological sequel

questions.correct_answer: D. The APGAR score at 1 minute is used to predict long-term neurological sequel

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic tests is most commonly used to confirm the presence of neonatal seizures?
What is the primary mechanism of neuronal injury in Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy?
Which of the following is NOT an assessment parameter in the Silverman-Anderson Score?
Which of the following best describes the role of antenatal corticosteroids in preventing Hyaline Membrane Disease?

options.label: A
options.text: They stimulate surfactant production in fetal lungs

options.label: B
options.text: They prevent alveolar collapse by stabilizing the alveolar membrane

options.label: C
options.text: They reduce the risk of infection that may lead to respiratory distress

options.label: D
options.text: They promote the clearance of lung fluid at birth

questions.correct_answer: A. They stimulate surfactant production in fetal lungs

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic radiographic finding in Transient tachypnea of newborn.
A term newborn is delivered with meconium-stained amniotic fluid and has poor tone, no respiratory effort and HR <100 bpm. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate intubation and suctioning of the trachea

options.label: B
options.text: Routine suctioning of the oropharynx and nose before stimulation

options.label: C
options.text: Provide positive pressure ventilation (PPV) if needed for resuscitation

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate administration of surfactant via endotracheal tub

questions.correct_answer: C. Provide positive pressure ventilation (PPV) if needed for resuscitation

questions.text: In newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia, the primary cause of respiratory distress is:
Which of the following findings is most suggestive of Persistent pulmonary hypertension of newborn rather than congenital cyanotic heart disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Differential cyanosis (pre-ductal SpO 2 higher than post-ductal SpO 2 )

options.label: B
options.text: A single S2 heart sound on auscultation

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperoxia test showing minimal improvement in PaO 2

options.label: D
options.text: Chest X-ray showing decreased pulmonary vascular markings

questions.correct_answer: A. Differential cyanosis (pre-ductal SpO 2 higher than post-ductal SpO 2 )

questions.text: Which of the following findings suggests pathological jaundice rather than physiological jaundice?

options.label: C
options.text: Jaundice persisting beyond 2 weeks in a term neonate

options.label: D
options.text: No evidence of hemolysis on peripheral smear

questions.correct_answer: C. Jaundice persisting beyond 2 weeks in a term neonate

questions.text: A preterm infant presents with abdominal distension, feeding intolerance, and bloody stools. Which radiographic finding is most specific for NEC?
Which neonatal reflex is used to assess brainstem integrity and is tested by turning the infant’s head to one side?
Which of the following is a common complication of cephalhematoma but NOT of caput succedaneum?
Which of the following is the primary mechanism leading to neonatal hypoglycaemia in preterm child
Out of the following definitive diagnostic test for biliary atresia is:
Which of the following best differentiates symmetrical IUGR from asymmetrical IUGR?

options.label: A
options.text: Head circumference is disproportionately large in symmetrical IUGR

options.label: B
options.text: Asymmetrical IUGR is usually due to early gestation insults

options.label: C
options.text: Symmetrical IUGR is commonly associated with genetic and congenital conditions

options.label: D
options.text: Asymmetrical IUGR results in proportionately small head and body size

questions.correct_answer: C. Symmetrical IUGR is commonly associated with genetic and congenital conditions

questions.text: A newborn is delivered at 32 weeks gestation with an axillary temperature of 35.5°C. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Place the baby under a radiant warmer and monitor temperature

options.label: B
options.text: Perform immediate resuscitation with positive pressure ventilation

options.label: D
options.text: Delay temperature correction and reassess in 30 minutes

questions.correct_answer: A. Place the baby under a radiant warmer and monitor temperature

questions.text: What is the primary physiological benefit of Kangaroo Mother Care for preterm infants?

options.label: D
options.text: Higher likelihood of spontaneous vaginal delivery

questions.correct_answer: B. Improved thermoregulation and reduced hypothermia

questions.text: Which of the following clinical signs is least specific for neonatal sepsis?
A 2-month-old infant with cholestasis undergoes a liver biopsy, revealing bile duct paucity. Which syndrome is most commonly associated with this finding?
Which of the following is the best long-term treatment approach for cystic fibrosis?
Which of the following infants is at highest risk for severe bronchiolitis and hospitalization?

options.label: A
options.text: A 6-month-old term infant with mild nasal congestion

options.label: B
options.text: A 3-week-old premature infant (born at 29 weeks) with chronic lung disease

questions.correct_answer: B. A 3-week-old premature infant (born at 29 weeks) with chronic lung disease

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a history of asthma presents with an acute exacerbation. His oxygen saturation is 88% on room air, and he has difficulty speaking in full sentences. On examination, he has decreased air entry with no audible wheezing. What is the most likely explanation for the absence of wheezing?

options.label: C
options.text: Silent chest due to severe airflow limitation

questions.correct_answer: C. Silent chest due to severe airflow limitation

questions.text: A person with an autosomal dominant disorder marries an unaffected individual. Which of the following scenarios could explain an unaffected child?

options.label: A
options.text: The child is a carrier but does not express the disorder

options.label: C
options.text: The child has a new mutation that prevents the disease

questions.correct_answer: B. The disorder shows incomplete penetrance

questions.text: Why do autosomal recessive disorders tend to be more common in consanguineous marriages?

options.label: A
options.text: Recessive mutations are more likely to be inherited from distant ancestors.

options.label: B
options.text: Carriers of recessive mutations are more common in certain ethnic groups.

options.label: C
options.text: There is a higher probability of inheriting two copies of the same recessive mutation.

options.label: D
options.text: Recessive mutations become dominant in consanguineous marriages.

questions.correct_answer: C. There is a higher probability of inheriting two copies of the same recessive mutation.

questions.text: A man with an X-linked dominant disorder has children with a healthy woman. What percentage of his daughters will inherit the disorder?
A woman who is a carrier for an X-linked recessive disorder has a child with an unaffected male. What is the probability that their daughter will be a carrier?
A mother with a mitochondrial disorder has four children. Two of them have severe symptoms, one has mild symptoms, and one is asymptomatic. What is the most likely explanation?

options.label: D
options.text: X-inactivation causing formation of barr bodies

questions.text: Which of the following trinucleotide repeat disorders follows X-linked inheritance?
Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for maintaining genomic imprinting across generations?
questions.correct_answer: C. DNA methylation and histone modifications

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of Down syndrome in a mother having age 34 years
Which of the following hormonal changes is expected in a patient with Klinefelter’s syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased testosterone, decreased FSH and LH

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased testosterone, increased FSH and LH

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased testosterone, decreased FSH and LH

options.label: D
options.text: Increased testosterone, increased FSH and LH

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased testosterone, increased FSH and LH

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common endocrine/metabolic issue seen in Turner syndrome?
A 6-month-old infant presents with fever, vomiting, and profuse watery diarrhea. Stool microscopy shows no fecal leukocytes. What is the most likely causative agent?
Which of the following laboratory findings is most commonly associated with severe dehydration due to diarrhea?
Which of the following complications is most commonly associated with untreated marasmus?
What is the first step in the management of a child with severe acute malnutrition

options.label: C
options.text: Slow correction of hypoglycemia and electrolyte imbalances

questions.correct_answer: C. Slow correction of hypoglycemia and electrolyte imbalances

questions.text: A 6-month-old exclusively breastfed infant without supplementation presents with seizures. Lab results show low serum calcium and elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH). What is the most likely cause?
A child with X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets presents with persistent pain despite treatment with phosphate supplements and calcitriol. What is the most likely cause of the persistent symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Secondary hyperparathyroidism due to phosphate therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Hypocalcemia due to vitamin D overdose

questions.correct_answer: A. Secondary hyperparathyroidism due to phosphate therapy

questions.text: Which of the following best explains why scurvy leads to easy bruising and delayed wound healing?

options.label: A
options.text: Deficiency of clotting factors due to vitamin C-dependent synthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Increased capillary fragility due to defective collagen formation

options.label: C
options.text: Suppression of platelet production in the bone marrow

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased capillary fragility due to defective collagen formation

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic changes is commonly seen in children with severe acute malnutrition?

options.label: D
options.text: Increased potassium retention by the kidneys

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency presents with early pubic hair, advanced bone age, and growth acceleration. What is the primary cause of these findings?
Which of the following is NOT a typical clinical feature of congenital hypothyroidism in a newborn?
Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with acquired hypothyroidism?

A 5-year-old boy presents with proportionate short stature, frontal bossing, and small hands and feet. His mother reports he was born with a normal birth weight but has grown poorly since infancy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A teenage boy presents with delayed puberty. Examination reveals eunuchoid body proportions, small testes, and gynecomastia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
A 7-year-old boy is diagnosed with peripheral precocious puberty. Which of the following findings would be inconsistent with this diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) after GnRH stimulation

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of adrenal mass on imaging

questions.correct_answer: A. Elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) after GnRH stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate acute management of a febrile seizure lasting more than 5 minutes?
Which of the following is true regarding the prognosis of childhood absence epilepsy?

options.label: A
options.text: It never remits and progresses to Lennox-Gastaut syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with a high risk of sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP)

questions.correct_answer: B. It usually resolves by adolescence

questions.text: A patient in refractory status epilepticus is not responding to benzodiazepines and second-line agents (phenytoin/levetiracetam). What is the next best step?

options.label: B
options.text: Intubate and start continuous infusion of propofol or midazolam

questions.correct_answer: B. Intubate and start continuous infusion of propofol or midazolam

questions.text: Which of the following epileptic syndromes is most commonly associated with hypsarrhythmia on EEG?
Which of the following vascular malformations is most characteristic of Sturge-Weber syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Capillary malformation affecting the trigeminal nerve distribution

questions.correct_answer: A. Capillary malformation affecting the trigeminal nerve distribution

questions.text: Which of the following clinical signs is least characteristic of cerebral palsy?
In suspected bacterial meningitis, which of the following is the most appropriate next step before performing a lumbar puncture?

options.label: B
options.text: Perform a CT scan of the head if there are focal neurological deficits

options.label: C
options.text: Obtain blood cultures and wait for results

options.label: D
options.text: Give corticosteroids as the first step

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform a CT scan of the head if there are focal neurological deficits

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic findings is most indicative of Duchenne muscular dystrophy?

options.label: C
options.text: Muscle biopsy showing absent dystrophin on immunohistochemistry

options.label: D
options.text: Progressive sensory neuropathy on nerve conduction studies

questions.correct_answer: C. Muscle biopsy showing absent dystrophin on immunohistochemistry

questions.text: What is the main reason why fetal circulation allows blood to bypass the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: The fetal lungs are non-functional and fluid-filled.

options.label: B
options.text: The placenta has a low resistance to blood flow.

options.label: C
options.text: The ductus arteriosus directs blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary hemodynamic consequence of an uncorrected atrial septal defect?

options.label: A
options.text: Right ventricular volume overload and pulmonary overcirculation

options.label: B
options.text: Left ventricular volume overload and pulmonary hypertension

options.label: C
options.text: Left ventricular hypertrophy and reduced cardiac output

questions.correct_answer: A. Right ventricular volume overload and pulmonary overcirculation

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for surgical closure of a VSD?

options.label: B
options.text: Left-to-right shunt with a Qp:Qs ratio < 1.5:1

options.label: C
options.text: Moderate-to-large VSD with signs of pulmonary overcirculation and failure to thrive

questions.correct_answer: C. Moderate-to-large VSD with signs of pulmonary overcirculation and failure to thrive

questions.text: A preterm infant with a large PDA is most likely to present with which of the following hemodynamic changes?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased systemic vascular resistance and increased diastolic blood pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased pulmonary blood flow and increased right ventricular afterload

options.label: C
options.text: Increased pulmonary overcirculation and decreased systemic perfusion

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased pulmonary overcirculation and decreased systemic perfusion

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary determinant of symptom severity in Tetralogy of Fallot?

options.label: A
options.text: Size of the ventricular septal defect

options.label: B
options.text: Degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of an atrial septal defect

questions.correct_answer: B. Degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction

questions.text: Which of the following echocardiographic findings is NOT characteristic of tricuspid atresia?
A neonate with TGA and an intact ventricular septum undergoes echocardiography. Which finding is most consistent with this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Aorta anterior and to the left of the pulmonary artery

options.label: B
options.text: Aorta anterior and to the right of the pulmonary artery

options.label: C
options.text: Aorta posterior to the pulmonary artery

options.label: D
options.text: Aorta and pulmonary artery arising from a single trunk

questions.correct_answer: B. Aorta anterior and to the right of the pulmonary artery

questions.text: What is the recommended long-term prophylaxis for a patient with a history of rheumatic fever with carditis and persistent valvular disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Monthly IM benzathine penicillin for 5 years

options.label: C
options.text: IM benzathine penicillin every 3 weeks until age 40 or lifelong

options.label: D
options.text: No prophylaxis needed after initial treatment

questions.correct_answer: C. IM benzathine penicillin every 3 weeks until age 40 or lifelong

questions.text: Which of the following complications is most strongly associated with nephrotic syndrome?
Which of the following is TRUE regarding the long-term prognosis of PSGN?

options.label: A
options.text: Most children recover completely without residual kidney damage

options.label: B
options.text: Adults have a better prognosis than children

options.label: C
options.text: Recurrence of PSGN is common with repeat streptococcal infections

options.label: D
options.text: End-stage renal disease develops in most cases

questions.correct_answer: A. Most children recover completely without residual kidney damage

questions.text: What is the best initial management for a child diagnosed with E. coli O157:H7-associated Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome?
A pregnant woman contracts primary varicella infection in the first trimester. Which of the following is a potential complication in the fetus?

options.label: C
options.text: Limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions

questions.correct_answer: C. Limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Congenital varicella syndrome (CVS) is characterized by limb hypoplasia, cicatricial (scarring) skin lesions, microcephaly, and eye abnormalities.
  • • • CMV → microcephaly + periventricular calcifications
  • • • Parvovirus B19 → hydrops fetalis + severe anemia
  • • • Syphilis → saddle nose + Hutchinson teeth

questions.text: A parent is concerned that their 24-month-old child is not yet combining two words. What is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Reassure and follow up at the 30-month visit

options.label: B
options.text: Refer for a hearing evaluation and speech therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Recommend watching educational videos to improve speech

questions.correct_answer: B. Refer for a hearing evaluation and speech therapy

questions.text: The most appropriate anthropometric indicator to assess obesity in children is:
A 2-year-old child with Kawasaki disease is receiving high-dose IVIG and aspirin. After 48 hours, the fever persists. What is the next best step?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer a second dose of IVIG

options.label: D
options.text: Switch aspirin to a different NSAID

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer a second dose of IVIG

questions.text: In a patient with IgA nephritis and nephrotic-range proteinuria, which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue symptomatic management as the disease is self-limiting

options.label: B
options.text: Initiate immunosuppressive therapy with corticosteroids and possibly additional agents

options.label: C
options.text: Perform a skin biopsy to confirm IgA deposition

options.label: D
options.text: Prescribe antibiotics for possible bacterial etiology

questions.correct_answer: B. Initiate immunosuppressive therapy with corticosteroids and possibly additional agents

questions.text: Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most commonly associated with high-risk neuroblastoma?
Which of the following factors is the most important predictor of prognosis in Wilms' tumor?

A 5-year-old child presents with pallor, fever, and easy bruising. Blood tests reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with blasts on the peripheral smear. Flow cytometry confirms B-cell ALL. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is associated with the worst prognosis?
